SENT.plain: Cerebral microbleeds (MBs) may relate to amyloid in dementia
We selected 26 probable Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients with MBs, 26 age- and sex-matched AD patients without MBs, 11 vascular dementia (VaD) patients, and 22 patients with subjective complaints
We measured amyloid beta 1-42 (Aβ42) and 1-40 (Aβ40) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and plasma, and blood-brain barrier (BBB) function using albumin ratios
CSF Aβ42 was lowest in AD with MBs, whereas Aβ40 was selectively decreased in VaD
In plasma, amyloid-beta was nonsignificantly elevated in VaD compared with controls
Higher albumin ratios in VaD suggested blood-brain barrier dysfunction
A MB pattern suggestive of cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) related to lower CSF Aβ42, while a non-cerebral amyloid angiopathy specific MB distribution related to higher plasma Aβ40
Amyloid-beta is differentially implicated in AD with MBs and VaD
MB distribution related to different amyloid profiles, supporting distinct etiologies
Our results suggest that Aβ42 is retained in cerebrovasculature of AD patients with MBs, while in contrast, VaD patients may possibly drain amyloid
